awd_titl_txt: Belmont Forum Collaborative Research: Guiding the pursuit for sustainability by            co-developing a Sustainable Agriculture Matrix (SAM)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides support to U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by a 55-country initiative on global change research through the Belmont Forum.  The Belmont Forum is a consortium of research funding organizations focused on support for transdisciplinary approaches to global environmental change challenges and opportunities.  It aims to accelerate delivery of the international research most urgently needed to remove critical barriers to sustainability by aligning and mobilizing international resources. Each partner country provides funding for their researchers within a consortium to alleviate the need for funds to cross international borders. This approach facilitates effective leveraging of national resources to support excellent research on topics of global relevance best tackled through a multinational approach, recognizing that global challenges need global solutions. This award provides support for the U.S. researchers to cooperate in consortia that consist of partners from at least three of the participating countries.  The teams will establish transdisciplinary networks to develop innovative solutions for sustainable development pathways and seek to assess the positive and negative inter-linkages between the economy, technology, institutions with the environment, climate, biodiversity, and human well-being to understand potential pathways to a sustainable world.

The project focuses on formulating pathways for sustainable agriculture by engaging with stakeholders to co-develop an indicator system and associated products that will measure agriculture sustainability.  The consortium will identify the inter-linkages among various sustainable development goals (SDGs) related to agriculture and identify strategies for advancing sustainable agriculture to help inform policy. To maximize the interactions and collaborations across the boundaries of disciplines, sectors, and nations, the consortium will organize a range of networking and co-learning activities, such as consortium-wide meetings, regular experience sharing and peer-learning sessions, and field visits.  The research team will also cultivate cross-country partnerships to investigate the historical trajectories of agriculture sustainability and to analyze tradeoffs between their developed indicators and SDGs in each region and the globe.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research (ICER)

inst.inst_name: University of Maryland Center for Environmental Sciences
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND CENTER FOR ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Maryland Center for Environmental Sciences

por.por_cntn:
[Overview]

Pursuing pathways towards sustainability relies on an agricultural sector that accounts for the social, economic, and environmental pillars of sustainability. However, while the concept of Sustainable Agriculture has been increasingly used by stakeholders and researchers, its definition varies and reliable methods to measure it remain elusive, leading to confusion in communication and lack of coordinated efforts by stakeholders. To address this challenge, we established a transdisciplinary and transnational network known as the Sustainable Agriculture Matrix (SAM) Consortium in order to guide pathways for sustainable agriculture by co-developing and disseminating an indicator system and associated products.

The SAM Consortium is a continuation of a previous three-year-long effort to develop an initial set of 18 indicators, which provides a first-of-its-kind quantitative assessment for the impacts of agriculture on environmental, social, and economic dimensions of sustainability for over 150 countries. To further integrate stakeholder feedback for improving indicators and associated tools, the SAM Consortium established transdisciplinary teams in six countries and regions with diverse socioeconomic and environmental profiles (i.e., Austria, Brazil, South Africa, Sub-Saharan Africa, Turkey, and the United States). During the course of the project, the Consortium focused on three Work Themes: 

1) Application. For each region, we conducted stakeholder workshops and co-developed country cases based on the initial SAM assessment identifying opportunities for future improvements of SAM. 

2) Analysis. We developed statistical analyses to explore the full range of tradeoffs and synergies among SAM indicators and between SAM indicators and Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

3) Dissemination. We broadened our audience through the development of communication products such as interactive web platforms and policy briefs which are accessible to various types of stakeholders. 

Overall, we successfully released the first edition of the SAM indicators (Zhang et al., 2021), and conducted 14 stakeholder workshops across 8 countries and involving 236 stakeholders. We hosted 3 online webinars in collaboration with stakeholders representing international institutions such as Oxfam and the Inter-American Development Bank (IADB). Additionally, we presented key findings and hosted sessions at various international conferences, all in an effort to disseminate SAM to a wider audience and ensure the longevity of this novel collaboration. Also of note, several interactive web platforms have been developed and published online (https://research.al.umces.edu/sam/). As the lead of the SAM Consortium, our US Working Group oversaw the coordination of this international collaborative in addition to managing the development of our own regional case study

 [Intellectual Merit]

This project pioneers scientific advancements on several fronts: 1) offering a first-of-its-kind global assessment of agricultural sustainability; 2) enhancing data quality for various indicators, especially nitrogen and phosphorus usage in agricultural production; 3) demystifying the intricate role of trade in agricultural sustainability; and 4) cultivating a transdisciplinary research approach that combines quantitative assessments with stakeholder input on trade-offs among sustainable agriculture indicators. Research insights corresponding to conference presentations and publications included development of a phosphorus budget database; novel analysis of nitrogen management in the context of tradeoffs and synergies with other SDGs; the dissemination of our first-of-its-kind monitoring system of sustainable agriculture (SAM); and contributions to FAOSTAT's Nutrient Database. These efforts resulted in multiple publications accepted in high-impact interdisciplinary journals such as Nature. Other notable outputs include policy briefs for country cases, a synthesis report of major trade-offs and synergies among agriculture-related SDGs and countries, and multiple communication products (e.g., SAM report cards, and an interactive web platform). By co-developing and analyzing quantitative SAM indicators, this project will continue to guide pathways to sustainability.

[Broader Impacts]

The SAM indicators and associated tools provide transparent and consistent assessment of agricultural sustainability on a national scale for countries around the world. Consequently, this benefits the international policy community in tracking a country's commitment to SDGs, and aids country governments in identifying priority areas and strategies for improvement.

The SAM consortium has engaged over 200 stakeholders from various sectors including government, research, NGOs, civil society, and agriculture. Their involvement has not only enriched the development of indicators and tools, ensuring practical utility for their work, but has also provided benefits to the stakeholders by fostering collaboration across national, disciplinary, and sectoral boundaries. Open dialogues among country partners have sparked critical reflection on the underrepresentation of developing country experts in SAM's initial edition. These discussions have nurtured a collaborative culture within the consortium, highlighting the value of contributions from all partners and diverse stakeholders, and ensuring the participation of developing countries in future editions of SAM.

The data developed for the SAM indicators, such as nitrogen and phosphorus surplus, have been utilized to develop the nutrient budget database hosted by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO). Leveraging this collaboration, we are exploring the possibility of integrating some SAM indicators into the official monitoring framework for SDGs.


Last Modified: 12/21/2023
Modified by: Xin Zhang
